message: by the way, I mean in vim, what are the shortcuts after I type :
(I know terminals can be set to vim mode, I'm assuming it's not)
So, if in normal mode I typed ":cd /my/dir" and realized that I wanted to change it to ":lcd /my/dir", is there some equivalent to ctrl-a in a terminal?
I can't find the docs on these

:help cmdline-editing will get you to the appropriate place in the the help docs to find the keyboard shortcuts you want. ctrl-b is the one you reference in your example (to go to the beginning of the line)
seems like it should paste the unnamed register, but it's pasting the clipboard instead
which even tells me how to paste on the command line, which I've wondered in the back of my head forever
Which leads to a followup question:
if I manually type <C-r>" or <C-r>*, they work as expected
https://github.com/houtsnip/vim-emacscommandline may interest you if you don't want to re-learn your emacsy readline shortcuts.
